attachments.title: Submit Your RSS/Atom Feed | juliabloggers.com
attachments.text: If you are interested in contributing your content to Julia Bloggers, fill out the form below. Please only submit an RSS/Atom feed for the specific tag on your blog related to Julia of which you are the original author. For example, on WordPress, the RSS feed link for a ‘Julia’ tag would look like: <http://randyzwitch.com/tag/julia/feed/> […]

messages.text: Common Franklin workflow seems to involve copying content of `__site` from the main branch into the `gh-pages` branch. But "copy a subdirectory into another branch" seems like a very weird thing to do in git. Is there a command to do this?

messages.text:
I have a question about choosing a good workflow. The blog part of my site works well with Franklin, but I had some photo galleries before which I want to add to the Franklin site as well.

I have folders with "originals" at relatively good resolution and thought it should be reasonably straightforward to make a script that goes through these folders, computes smaller preview / thumbnail versions, and then creates the pages that show them.

What I'm confused about is where to put the main script, where to generate the pages with images, where to best store the thumbnails (they should only be generated at deployment).

Currently I have a main `index.md` in a `photography` top folder, and in that only the command `{{ generate_galleries }}`. The images are in the `_assets` folder in one subfolder per album. Do I generate `md` files in `hfun_generate_galleries` and put them in subfolders of `photography`? I don't have a good understanding where in the build sequence I should insert my generated content. Should I generate the thumbnails into the generated `asset` folder?

    return """
    <a href="www.google.com">google</a>
    """
end```
when I click the link on the webpage it tries to go to `path/to/current/page/<http://www.google.com|www.google.com>`

messages.text: ^ the `libuv` errors are known and due to the HTTP library, typically when you close and reopen tabs of your browser, refresh pages at "unexpected" times or whatever. It's not on Franklin's side (and it's annoying but it can be safely ignored, it won't affect anything) (see doc FAQ for more)

messages.text: Hi everyone. I am trying to generate a table from a embedded script in a .md file and save the output to a csv file. Exactly the same way it is done in Franklin's documentation, saving the result using `write("assets/table.csv")`. However, when the script is run, I get `SystemError: opening file "assets/table.csv": No such file or directory` I have tried to remove __site and regenerate it from scratch without any luck. It seems to work if I save it to _assets/table.csv, but I am unsure about whether this is the intended usage.  Am I missing something? Thanks for your help!

elements.text: Hi everyone. I am trying to generate a table from a embedded script in a .md file and save the output to a csv file. Exactly the same way it is done in Franklin's documentation, saving the result using
. However, when the script is run, I get
SystemError: opening file "assets/table.csv": No such file or directory

I have tried to remove __site and regenerate it from scratch without any luck. It seems to work if I save it to _assets/table.csv, but I am unsure about whether this is the intended usage.  Am I missing something? Thanks for your help!

messages.text: Hi. I guess this is a feature request. At first, I misunderstood the aim of `@def reeval = true`. I see now that it forces the execution of all blocks, regardless of them being modified or not, right? But that is not what I was actually in need of. For the sake of organizing some of the post (specially those that are not about the underlying code, but about the math itself), I put the code at the end, so I need to get the page compiled twice to effectively see the changes. It is not a big deal to just change part of the text to have that effect, but it would be nicer to just tell Franklin to go over the file twice so it updates the code outputs properly (it doesn’t need to reevaluate the codes since they will not be changed, it is just for the sake of getting the output right). It should be a local variable as well, which defaults to false, but that we could add to specific pages with say `@def passtwice = true`. Is it easy to do something like this?

elements.text: Hi. I guess this is a feature request. At first, I misunderstood the aim of

. I see now that it forces the execution of all blocks, regardless of them being modified or not, right? But that is not what I was actually in need of. For the sake of organizing some of the post (specially those that are not about the underlying code, but about the math itself), I put the code at the end, so I need to get the page compiled twice to effectively see the changes. It is not a big deal to just change part of the text to have that effect, but it would be nicer to just tell Franklin to go over the file twice so it updates the code outputs properly (it doesn’t need to reevaluate the codes since they will not be changed, it is just for the sake of getting the output right). It should be a local variable as well, which defaults to false, but that we could add to specific pages with say
. Is it easy to do something like this?

messages.text:
Hi, first, kudos to Franklin :tada:.

I want to use it to deploy two websites, one related to a project (GitHub organisation) using the `<http://orgname.github.io|orgname.github.io>` landing page and one related to a teaching where a `<http://orgname.github.io/myWebsite/|orgname.github.io/myWebsite/>` landing would be preferred.

I followed the workflow described at <https://franklinjl.org/workflow/#creating_your_website> using the `basic` theme. I modified some pages and kept a minimal layout. The `serve()` produces expected output locally and all seems to be fine.

However, my deploy fails on GitHub, although I followed the suggested steps (<https://franklinjl.org/workflow/deploy/#deploying_on_github>). My local folder’s content is indeed on my `<http://orgname.github.io|orgname.github.io>` repo and the green tick shows up after some 20 seconds. It looks like the `__site/` folder does not make it to the `gh-pages` branch, the latter not being created “automatically” by the GitHub workflow (as expected?). Do I miss something obvious ? Looks like I do not have `.github/workflows` in the repo and my only branch is `main` not `master`.

Any help and suggestions welcome. The repo is accessible here <https://github.com/PTsolvers/PTsolvers.github.io>

• <https://julialang.org/blog/2020/08/invalidations/#an_example_compilation_for_containers_with_unknown_element_types>

attachments.title: Analyzing sources of compiler latency in Julia: method invalidations
attachments.text: Julia runs fast, but suffers from latency due to compilation. This post analyzes one source of excess compilation, tools for detecting and eliminating its causes, and the impact this effort has had on latency.
attachments.fallback: Analyzing sources of compiler latency in Julia: method invalidations

elements.text: I noticed that recently pages built with Franklin display a deprecation notice (related to highlight.js) above code blocks:

Hello Everyone, i am using Franklin for our webiste and i am facing one issue, Latest articles and press release articles are not getting indexed in Google news. Please let me know if anyone can help me to rectify this issue.

messages.text:
Is there an API reference somewhere for the Franklin.jl package itself? Or for commands usable in pages? Eg on <https://franklinjl.org/workflow/structure/|this page>, there's an example block with `{{ispage blog/*}} {{insert head_blog}}{{end}}`. `ispage` has some documentation <https://franklinjl.org/syntax/page-variables/index.html#conditional_blocks|here>, but I can't find where `insert` is documented. Similarly, things like `{{fill x}}` <https://franklinjl.org/syntax/page-variables/index.html#for_loops|here> aren't super clear, but I can't find other documentation.

Separately, I found the function in the <http://julialang.org|julialang.org> `utils.jl` file to generate blogposts, and they use the `pagevar` function, which <https://franklinjl.org/search/index.html?q=pagevar|I can't find> on the docs page, but which does have a docstring from the REPL

messages.text: JuliaGPU has joined the bandwagon: <https://juliagpu.org> :party_corgi:

For folks who recently had issue with RSS, there's now a working fix + explanations on how to use the fix (it's easy) <https://github.com/tlienart/Franklin.jl/pull/799> . It will be released soon (I only need to add more tests). The fix should bring stuff back to working and also generally allow you to take full control over the design of your `feed.xml` file.

messages.text: So does franklin generate the navigation bar/site map for you based on some configuration file (i.e, the way it Documenter.jl would)?  Or do you just manually edit the HTML in the headers?

elements.text: So does franklin generate the navigation bar/site map for you based on some configuration file (i.e, the way it Documenter.jl would)?  Or do you just manually edit the HTML in the headers?

messages.text: That's less of a Franklin thing and more of a HTML/CSS theme thing. Some of the provided templates might already have some of the infrastructure there for you though.

elements.text: That's less of a Franklin thing and more of a HTML/CSS theme thing. Some of the provided templates might already have some of the infrastructure there for you though.

messages.text: <@U9Q2CBDMZ>: Tyler is on point, the layout and design is fully on your side though FranklinTemplates.jl provides starting points with different styles (see <https://tlienart.github.io/FranklinTemplates.jl/|this page>). You can then completely deviate from it and use your own template by modifying the `_layout` and `_css` files (and potentially `_libs` if you require specific javascript libs).

messages.text: Yeah that makes sense.  I was sort of expecting it to coming over from Documenter (though, there's really no reason that I should have), and so I spent a lot of time scratching my head and looking through repos to find a config file that didn't exist.
